and to clarify the reason I'm asking about the indexes...IQ is extremely efficient at doing joins like this when properly indexed, especially if those "lookup_n" columns have a relatively low cardinality.  It doesn't jump out at me as likely to perform poorly, even with the 12 joins.

I know you want us to just write a more efficient query without getting bogged down in other details, and I'm willing, but I think it's important to cover the Sybase IQ fundamentals first. I would not recommend using a "join" index, as it's deprecated on newer versions of IQ.  Do you have "HG" or "LF" indexes on all of the "lookup_n" columns of the raw event table? Is lookup_id the primary key of lookup_table, if not, does it at least have an HG index on it?  IQ is extremely efficient at storage space, if they're not indexed I can't think of a good reason why you should not add them.

. . I doubt it. Tables are inherently unordered. DB2 (to the best of my knowledge) doesn't offer a way to express a default sort order, and I doubt that COBOL would override this. @coder: no, you don't need this for the insert to product_purchase_item (if your intent is to insert a new row.) You'd only use this if you wanted to do an "UPDATE OR INSERT" type operation, depending on whether the INSERT operation would violate a unique key constraint. (Note that in the case of an UPDATE action, an AFTER INSERT trigger will not be fired.)

@coder: the INSERT ... ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE is a single statement that will perform an insert, but if a "duplicate key" exception is raised (i.e. a value already exists in a unique index), then the UPDATE action will be performed. My SQL Fiddle demo (ref'd in comment above) shows a trigger that does eseentially the same thing the body of your trigger is doing: checking if a row already exists, and then performing an update or an insert.

I have tested, and confirmed that there is an issue with "gaps" in AUTO_INCREMENT caused by the INSERT ... ON DUPLICATE KEY which occurs in MySQL 5.1.53 using InnoDB. Here is a demonstration of the same behavior in 5.1.61 SQL Fiddle here: http://sqlfiddle.com/#!8/509ef/1

The INSERT statement in the OP trigger has three columns (according to the list of values in the insert), with a NULL supplied for that first (unnamed) column. It was this (unnamed) column I assumed had AUTO_INCREMENT. There's no indication, in the OP trigger code that the second column, named product_id, is AUTO_INCREMENT. The INSERT ... ON DUPLICATE KEY approach requires a UNIQUE constraint on product_stock(product_id). The missing AUTO_INCREMENT values I was concerned with would be on this (unnamed) column, not the product_id column that I mistakenly identified. I will test.

"+" is not the concatenation operator, your example will fail if there is a non-numeric column. Even if you use the proper concatenation, it won't work correctly in many cases. For example 'a' || null || 'c' and 'a' || 'b' || null will both return NULL, while the intent obviously would be to treat these combinations as different. On the other hand, one NULL value is not equal to another NULL value, so 'a' || null || 'c' and 'a' || null || 'c' will not be equal either, though intent in this case would be to treat them as equal.

With Decimal Datatypes we can optionally use precision and scale. Precision is the maximum total number of decimal digits that will be stored, both to the left and to the right of the decimal point. The precision must be a value from 1 through the maximum precision of 38. The default precision is 18.
And Scale is the number of decimal digits that will be stored to the right of the decimal point. This number is subtracted from p to determine the maximum number of digits to the left of the decimal point. Scale must be a value from 0 through p.

It's very important to make sure every sqlite3_open has a sqlite3_close and that every sqlite3_prepare_v2 has a sqlite3_finalize.
